contents.text: Support in High-Stakes Public Sector Decision-Making

contents.label: section-title
contents.text: Internal actors and machine learning–driven decisions

contents.label: section-title
contents.text: Gaming by decision-support users ‘Gaming’ or manipulation of data-driven systems, and the con- cern of this occurring if greater transparency is introduced, is often raised as an issue in relation to the targets of algorithmic decisions. This will be discussed in a following section. Yet types of internal gaming within organisations have received considerably less treatment by those concerned about value- laden challenges around algorithmically informed decisions. This is despite how internal gaming is extensively highlighted in the public administration literature in relation to targets and the rise of New Public Management [7], a broad movement to- wards ‘rationalisation’ in the public sector that clearly affected informants around the world.
